storyTitle: As Schedule Coordinator, I want to track the status of my schedule change requests to achieve transparency and timely updates

testCases.title: Validate display of user's schedule change requests
preconditions: User has valid Schedule Coordinator credentials
Schedule Coordinator has previously submitted at least 5 schedule change requests with varying statuses (Pending, Approved, Rejected)
Database contains schedule change requests with approval history and comments
Application is accessible and running
Network connectivity is stable

steps.action: Navigate to the application login page and enter valid Schedule Coordinator credentials (username and password), then click the Login button
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully authenticated and redirected to the dashboard. Dashboard displays a list of all schedule change requests submitted by the logged-in Schedule Coordinator with columns showing request ID, date submitted, request type, current status, and action buttons

steps.action: Locate the status filter dropdown on the dashboard and select 'Pending' from the available status options, then click Apply or wait for auto-refresh
steps.expectedResult: The request list dynamically updates to display only schedule change requests with 'Pending' status. All other status requests are filtered out. The count of displayed requests matches the number of pending requests. Filter indicator shows 'Status: Pending' is active

steps.action: Click on one of the pending requests from the filtered list to open the detailed view
steps.expectedResult: A detailed view modal or page opens displaying comprehensive information including: request details (ID, type, date submitted, requested changes), complete approval history with timestamps, all comments from approvers and stakeholders, current status with status change timeline, and assigned approver information. All data displayed is accurate and matches the selected request

postconditions: User remains logged in as Schedule Coordinator
Dashboard maintains the applied filter state
Detailed view can be closed to return to the filtered list
No data has been modified during the test

testCases.title: Verify notifications on status changes
preconditions: User has valid Schedule Coordinator credentials
User has valid Approver credentials for testing approval actions
Notification system is enabled and configured
User has notification preferences enabled for status updates
Email or in-app notification delivery system is functional
Database is accessible and can record status changes

steps.action: Log in as Schedule Coordinator, navigate to the schedule change request submission form, fill in all required fields (date, time, reason, affected resources), and click Submit button
steps.expectedResult: Schedule change request is successfully created and saved to the database. Request appears in the Schedule Coordinator's dashboard with initial status 'Pending'. Confirmation message displays 'Request submitted successfully' with the assigned request ID

steps.action: Log out from Schedule Coordinator account. Log in with Approver credentials, navigate to pending approvals queue, locate the newly submitted request, review the details, and change the status to 'Approved' by clicking the Approve button and adding approval comments
steps.expectedResult: Request status is updated to 'Approved' in the system. Approval action is recorded in the approval history with timestamp, approver name, and comments. Schedule Coordinator receives a notification (email and/or in-app) indicating that their request has been approved, including request ID, approval timestamp, and approver comments

steps.action: Log out from Approver account. Log back in as Schedule Coordinator, navigate to 'My Schedule Changes' dashboard, and locate the previously submitted request in the list
steps.expectedResult: The dashboard displays the request with updated status showing 'Approved'. The status change is reflected accurately with the approval timestamp. Opening the detailed view shows the complete approval history including the approver's name, approval time, and comments. Notification indicator (if applicable) shows the status change notification as received

postconditions: Schedule change request status remains 'Approved' in the database
Notification record is logged in the system
Approval history is permanently recorded
Schedule Coordinator can view the approved request details at any time
System is ready for subsequent status changes

testCases.title: Ensure dashboard loads within performance requirements
preconditions: User has valid Schedule Coordinator credentials
Database contains at least 50 schedule change requests for the user to simulate realistic load
System is under normal load conditions (not peak hours)
Network latency is within acceptable range (<100ms)
Browser cache is cleared to ensure accurate load time measurement
Performance monitoring tools or browser developer tools are available to measure load times

steps.action: Open browser developer tools and navigate to the Network tab to monitor page load times. Navigate to the application login page, enter valid Schedule Coordinator credentials, and click Login button. Start measuring time from login submission to complete dashboard render
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully authenticated and the dashboard page loads completely. The dashboard displays with all schedule change requests visible. Total page load time from authentication to full dashboard render (including all API calls and UI rendering) is 3 seconds or less. Network tab shows successful API response for GET /api/schedule-changes/my-requests

steps.action: On the loaded dashboard, note the current timestamp. Click on the 'Load More' or refresh button to reload the list of submitted requests. Measure the time from action initiation to complete list display
steps.expectedResult: The list of schedule change requests reloads successfully showing all user's submitted requests with current statuses. Load time for the request list is 3 seconds or less. All request data including ID, date, type, and status are displayed correctly. No timeout errors or loading failures occur

steps.action: Apply multiple filters simultaneously: select date range (last 30 days) and status filter (Pending). Note the timestamp when Apply button is clicked. Measure the time until the filtered results are fully displayed
steps.expectedResult: Filtered list loads and displays only requests matching the selected criteria (last 30 days AND Pending status). Response time from filter application to complete filtered list display is 3 seconds or less. Filter indicators show active filters correctly. Request count updates to reflect filtered results. Performance remains within SLA despite multiple filter conditions

postconditions: Dashboard remains functional and responsive
All filters remain applied and can be cleared
Performance metrics are logged for analysis
User session remains active
No performance degradation observed for subsequent operations

storyTitle: As System Administrator, I want to configure notification templates for schedule change workflows to achieve consistent communication

testCases.title: Validate creation and editing of notification templates
preconditions: User has valid System Administrator credentials
Administrator role has full permissions for notification template management
Notification templates management module is deployed and accessible
Database has NotificationTemplates table with proper schema
At least one existing notification template is present in the system for editing
Application is running and accessible

steps.action: Navigate to the application login page, enter valid System Administrator credentials (username and password), click Login button, then navigate to the Administration section and click on 'Notification Templates' menu item
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully authenticated with administrator privileges. Notification templates management page loads displaying a list of existing templates with columns for template name, type, last modified date, and action buttons (Edit, Delete, Preview). 'Create New Template' button is visible and accessible at the top of the page

steps.action: Click the 'Create New Template' button. In the template creation form, enter template name 'Schedule Change Approved', select template type 'Approval Notification', enter subject line 'Your Schedule Change Request {{requestId}} has been Approved', enter body content with placeholders: 'Dear {{coordinatorName}}, Your schedule change request {{requestId}} submitted on {{submissionDate}} has been approved by {{approverName}} on {{approvalDate}}. Comments: {{approverComments}}', then click Save button
steps.expectedResult: Template creation form accepts all input fields. All placeholders are recognized and highlighted in the editor. Template is successfully saved to the database. Success message displays 'Template created successfully'. New template appears in the templates list with correct name, type, and current timestamp as creation date. Template ID is generated and assigned

steps.action: Locate the newly created template 'Schedule Change Approved' in the templates list and click the Edit button. Modify the subject line to 'Schedule Change Request {{requestId}} - Approved', update the body content to add 'Please review the updated schedule at your earliest convenience.', then click Save button
steps.expectedResult: Template opens in edit mode with all previously saved content populated correctly. Subject and body fields are editable. Modified content is accepted. Template saves successfully with updated content. Success message displays 'Template updated successfully'. Template list shows updated 'Last Modified' timestamp. Opening the template again shows the saved changes accurately reflected

postconditions: New notification template exists in the database with all specified content
Template modifications are permanently saved
Template is available for assignment to workflow events
Audit log records template creation and modification actions
Administrator remains logged in and can perform additional operations

testCases.title: Verify template preview functionality
preconditions: User has valid System Administrator credentials and is logged in
At least one notification template exists with multiple placeholders
Template contains placeholders such as {{requestId}}, {{coordinatorName}}, {{approverName}}, {{submissionDate}}, {{approvalDate}}, {{approverComments}}
Sample data is configured in the system for preview functionality
Template rendering engine is functional and configured

steps.action: From the notification templates management page, locate an existing template with placeholders (e.g., 'Schedule Change Approved'), and click the Edit button to open the template in edit mode
steps.expectedResult: Template editor opens displaying the complete template content. Subject line and body content are visible with all placeholders clearly marked (e.g., highlighted or in a different color). Template metadata (name, type, last modified) is displayed. Preview button is visible and enabled in the editor toolbar

steps.action: Click the 'Preview with Sample Data' button in the template editor toolbar
steps.expectedResult: Preview modal or panel opens displaying the rendered template. All placeholders are replaced with realistic sample data: {{requestId}} shows 'REQ-12345', {{coordinatorName}} shows 'John Smith', {{approverName}} shows 'Jane Doe', {{submissionDate}} shows '2024-01-15', {{approvalDate}} shows '2024-01-16', {{approverComments}} shows 'Approved as requested. No conflicts found.' The rendered template displays in the same format as end users would receive it (email format with proper formatting, line breaks, and styling). Template renders within 1 second of clicking preview button. Preview clearly shows how the final notification will appear to recipients

postconditions: Preview modal can be closed without affecting the template
Template content remains unchanged after preview
Administrator can continue editing after closing preview
Preview can be generated multiple times without issues
System performance remains stable after preview rendering

testCases.title: Ensure unauthorized users cannot manage templates
preconditions: User has valid non-administrator credentials (e.g., Schedule Coordinator role)
Non-admin user does not have administrator privileges or template management permissions
Role-based access control (RBAC) is properly configured in the system
API endpoints for template management have proper authorization checks
Notification templates management page exists and requires admin role
Security middleware is active and enforcing authorization rules

steps.action: Navigate to the application login page, enter valid non-administrator user credentials (e.g., Schedule Coordinator username and password), click Login button, then attempt to navigate to the notification templates management page by entering the URL directly in the browser address bar (e.g., /admin/notification-templates) or by accessing it through the navigation menu if visible
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully authenticated with non-administrator role. When attempting to access the notification templates management page, access is denied. User is either redirected to the dashboard or an 'Access Denied' or '403 Forbidden' error page is displayed with message 'You do not have permission to access this resource' or similar. Navigation menu does not show 'Notification Templates' option for non-admin users. Page content for template management is not rendered or accessible

steps.action: Using an API testing tool (e.g., Postman, browser developer console, or curl), attempt to directly access the notification template management API endpoints: GET /api/notification-templates (list templates), POST /api/notification-templates (create template), PUT /api/notification-templates/{id} (update template), DELETE /api/notification-templates/{id} (delete template). Use the authentication token of the logged-in non-admin user for these API calls
steps.expectedResult: All API endpoint requests are rejected with HTTP 403 Forbidden status code. Response body contains error message indicating insufficient permissions, such as 'Access denied. Administrator role required' or 'Unauthorized: You do not have permission to manage notification templates'. No template data is returned in the response. No create, update, or delete operations are executed. API security logs record the unauthorized access attempts with user ID and timestamp. System remains secure and does not expose sensitive template management functionality to unauthorized users

postconditions: Non-admin user remains logged in with their original role and permissions
No unauthorized changes were made to notification templates
Security audit log contains records of access denial
System security integrity is maintained
User can continue to access features appropriate to their role
No security vulnerabilities are exposed
